contextId.information: This does not mean that they were the sons of prophets, but rather, that they were a group of prophets. AT: "A group of men who were prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This does not mean that they were the sons of prophets, but rather, that they were a group of prophets. See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:02:03|2:3]]. AT: "the group of men who were prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This does not mean that they were the sons of prophets, but rather, that they were a group of prophets. See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:02:03|2:3]]. AT: "the group of men who were prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This does not mean that they were the sons of prophets, but rather, that they were a group of prophets. See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:02:03|2:3]]. AT: "the group of prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that something remains in a certain condition until the present time. AT: "by the word which Elisha spoke, and have always remained pure since" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The young boys wanted Elisha to go away from them and expressed this by saying "go up." AT: "Go away" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

"Turning away" from something is an idiom which means to stop doing it. AT: "he did not stop committing those sins" (UDB) or "he continued committing those sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: he did not turn away from them

contextId.information: This idiom means that he was Elijah's helper. The phrase "poured water on the hands" is a description of one of the ways he served Elijah. AT: "who was a helper to Elijah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: who poured water on the hands of Elijah

contextId.information: This does not mean that they were the sons of prophets, but rather, that they were a group of prophets. See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:02:03|2:3]]. AT: "the prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom. It means to use the money to buy the things that they need, such as food and clothing. AT: "use the rest of the money for you and your sons for what you need to live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: live with your sons on the rest

contextId.information: The phrase "gone to all this trouble" is an idiom that means to make great effort to do something. AT: "You have made a great effort to care for us" or "You have worked very hard to take care of us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: You have gone to all this trouble to care for us

contextId.information: This is an idiom. It does not mean that they were actually the sons of prophets, but rather, that they were a group of prophets. See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:02:03|2:3]]. AT: "the group of men who were prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This word is used here to draw someone's attention to what is said next. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This word is used here to draw someone's attention to what is said next. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The phrase "his presence" refers to the area where Elisha could see him. This means that he left the room where Elisha was. AT: "When Gehazi left the room, he was" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: So Gehazi went out from his presence

contextId.information: This does not mean that they were the sons of prophets, but rather, that they were a group of prophets. See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:02:03|2:3]]. AT: "The group of prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Elisha is asking that his servant may be able to see things that other people cannot see, namely the horses and chariots of fire that are around them. AT: "make him able to see"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: open his eyes that he may see

contextId.information: "To be before the king" means to be one of his servants. AT: "The king of Israel sent one of his servants as a messenger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: The king sent a man from before him

contextId.information: Here "walking" is an idiom that refers to how he lived and reigned as king. At this time in history, the recent kings of Israel had been evil kings. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. AT: "Jehoram was an evil king, just as other kings of Israel who ruled before him had been" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Jehoram walked in the ways of the kings of Israel

contextId.information: Here "walking" refers his behavior or the way in which he lived. AT: "Ahaziah lived the same way as the others in" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Ahaziah walked in the ways of

contextId.information: This does not mean that they were the sons of prophets, but rather, that they were a group of prophets. See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:02:03|2:3]]. AT: "the group of the prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
To "be on someone's side" means to be loyal to them and supportive of them. AT: "loyal to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that they were supervising them and teaching them. AT: "who were raising them" or "who were supervising them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means to capture them, but not to kill them. AT: "Seize them!" (UDB) or "Capture them!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "to keep" something means to care for it and oversee it. AT: "who was in charge of the priest's wardrobe" or "who cared for the priest's wardrobe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that something has remained in a certain condition until the present time. AT: "and since then it has always been that way" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: which it is to this day

contextId.information: The idiom "with all his heart" means "completely" and "with all his soul" means "with all his being." These two phrases have similar meanings. AT: "with all his being" or "with all his energy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: with all his heart and all his soul

contextId.information: This idiom means to "obey the terms of the covenant." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
